reviewText: There must be something wrong with this adaptation. The dialogues are off, and it horribly feels like something is missing from the gameplay itself. There's no indication of the notes on the distaff, and the drafts are almost impossible to play. I had to give up after a while, and this is seriously aggravating because I remember this game very fondly.\nI advise not to buy this version. It is horribly adapted.
voteText: 61 of 69 people (88%) found this review helpful

reviewText: Loom is unique. There is no game quite like it in the history of video games. As a professional singer and music teacher of many instruments, I still love the challenge of musical pattern recognition and recall of this wonderfully interesting game. I just saw the manual too and gosh, what a lovely throwback to the past when games really were works of art one could keep in the packaging and manuals that came with it. The music geek in me loves how one is supposed to use pencil to dictate the melodies one encounters in the game. It may be slow going for many of us (myself included) who are now so used to faster paced narratives in video games and other media; however, there is such a charm to it as well as some rather fiendish puzzles that had me cheating via online hint guides which incidentally one would have to pay and arm and a leg for with Lucas Arts hintlines, or so I hear. I give Loom 5 stars out of 5 for absolutely everything though I wish I could make bloody Bobbin Threadbare move far quicker- He is a tad snail like in his gait. Regardless, do play this gem while you have to chance. It is one of the best in the genre of adventure games and one of LucasArts finest offerings in this Musician's humble opinion :) Enjoy, Loom everyone. I am on my 4th playthrough and here's to many more :)
voteText: 26 of 27 people (96%) found this review helpful

reviewText: I really hate to say I don't reccomend this game, but as some other people have said, it's unfortunately the inferior version. I have played the EGA version all the way through and I think it's a pretty good game. I wouldn't rank it high among the LucasArts classics, but definitely something worth checking out. It's got a good plot and has an interesting take on the point and click genre; the only item here is a staff that can play music to perform a draft. You learn more and more of them as you play through the game, and use each draft to help get you through a puzzle. It's a fairly short game, but a good one.\n\nUnfortunately, LucasArts decided to include the CD version of this game instead of the EGA or FM-Towns version. While it has updated 256-color VGA graphics and voice acting, all of the dialogue and music had to be stored as CD audio. The voice acting is sloppily done at times and the music doesn't play very often, killing a lot of immersion. They also cut down the dialogue considerably, leading to some rather confusing moments in the plot. It's really a shame; I'd love to reccomend this game, but I just can't. There is a site that offers the FM-Towns version though, if you have bought this version. Since that's generally considered the best version (it has all the positives of both PC editions and none of the negatives of either), I'd say go on ahead and buy it and follow their method to obtain it.

reviewText:
Pick this one up, turn it on and ignore it while you emulate the proper EGA version.

Slightly better graphics and a poor voice-over track does not make up for the sheer amount of content that has been censored or cut from the original EGA version of this game.

That said, I'm so very glad that I finally played this. It was complete delight to get from beginning to end and I am absolutely floored that nothing else became of this game. It is a true LucasArts gem.

reviewText:
While not perfect this game surely represent one of the many steps the great LucasFilm (then LucasArts) took in its way to glory.

The game per se is a short, straightforward and thus much enjoayble, point and click adventure with one of the most efficient and minimalistic User Interface. Your Distaff (a musical stick) and a square for closeups of interactive items.

By any modern standard is a little thing, there are better indie products for (probably) less cash, but for one thing.

This game has a soul that begs to be found.
It asks to be played, remembered and passed on the next generation.

Maybe it's a combination of music, colours, and the memories of when I played it at the sweet age of eight.
If you decide to play it- take your time with it: get a pen and a paper, a hot beverage and just glide through it- much like a swan would do on the surface of a crystal-like calm lake.

It's all it asks. And it doesn't take up that much time. It may really leave you something unexpected.
:)

As part of a Lucasarts bundle I had this adventure for a long time. When I was a child I read in those paper things called videogames magazines about many graphic adventures nd one of those was Loom. In these days I had a chance to play something so I decided to start Loom... And Finish it. The playtime over there is correct. But let's talk about it later...
Loom is a graphic adventure directed by Brian Moriarty that sees You as Bobbin, a recluse and almost despised wizard apprentice. Bobbin is summoned by the elders of the village and for some odd reason they're all transformed into swans along with all the villagers, then they fly away. Now bobbin is the last of his village and can pick up his staff to go and search all the lost swans. VERY abridged version.
The very innovative interface of the game requires the use of the aforementioned distaff" which can play all seven notes ( you start with three
date: and unlock one by one the other ones as you proceed with the game). You can combine the notes into quartets to perform determined actions... Or better

reviewText: What a strange little game.  Of all the point-and-click adventure games I've endeavoured, this one is by far the shortest.  Although a bit convoluted at times, the plot is an interesting little adventure with seemingly huge obstacles that can be bypassed with a unique game mechanic: a musical stick.  The graphics and environments are lovely, and very importantly, the voice acting is fitting.  I also finally feel like I'm on the inside of the LucasArts secret club.  Finally, all those obscure Monkey Island references to this game make sense!\n\nDefinitely give it a play.  It's a quick little adventure with a famous classical piece as the backdrop.  You really can't go wrong, and you'll be singing Swan Lake tunes for the rest of the day.

reviewText:
AUDIO: Peaceful                                                 AESTHETIC: Beautiful
MEMORABILITY: Nostalgic                                 WORTH: Full PRice

PROS: Mysterious and alluring world that is rich with lore. Interesting musical system, no hand-holding. Nice voice-acting.

CONS: First game of a planned trilogy that never came to fruition. Starting the first game to a project that's been unfinished for around 25 years now may sound completely absurd to people who have never played Loom. Understandably so. Many different versions of Loom were released, and I'm disappointed to see that this was not a version cobbled together for the most content available.

OVERALL: A piece of point and click history.

SCORE: 10/10
voteText: 9 of 10 people (90%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Classic DOS game!
In the 25 years since its release, LOOM still finds a way to enchant all those who come across it.

An interesting and creative take on Tchaikovsky's ballet, Swan Lake, you play as the young Bobbin Threadbare of the Weavers who upon his birthday discovers that an evil is fastly approaching and intends to consume the world. When the Weavers depart from their world, Bobbin must venture from his village to reunite with his people and unwittingly uncovers a plot to seize control of all humanity.

Personally, I rate LOOM with a moderate difficulty. Those who are not familiar with the DOS action-adventure games of old may find the controls a bit tricky, especially in regards to Bobbin's Distaff, an instrument with which he can cast spells called Drafts that take the form of small pieces of music.

The key to this game is exploration, investigation, and patience. Interact with everything and everyone you come across and attempt spells on them to unlock bits of dialogue and helpful clues as to how to move forward throughout the game. Some puzzles are easy and quite straightforward while others.... not so much. The story, however, is worth all the trouble.

Classical music aficionados will also recognize samplings from the ballet within the game's score.

Length: 2-3 hours, if explored properly.

reviewText: Loom is a LucasArts game that started it all.  It's a point and click adventure game of old that instead of utilizing inventory as puzzles it uses musical spells.  Help Bobbin, your character, save the universe.  Old school graphics with great wonderful sound and a story that is very fun to follow.  This is a short and enjoyable old-school game.

reviewText:
One of the adventure-games of Lucasarts which took a different approach at adventure-gameplay.

In Loom you take over the control of Bobbin Threadbare, a member of the guild of weavers.
There is no inventory whatsoever, the only thing you're equipped with, is a magical staff.
With this staff you can cast tunes (or spells if you like; you just need to click on a certain part of the staff to play a note; four notes will make a tune).
As you progress, you learn more and more tunes which you can cast onto different items, persons or other objects.

I really like the mysterious and strange fantasy-world, though the game is not very long, nor is it very challenging but still, for me Loom is a rare pearl in adventure gaming.

Sadly, the plans to make it a trilogy were never fulfilled, so it feels a but unresolved at the end.

So, what is good in Loom? First of all, it is a beautiful game with charming backgrounds. The most important part of game - the story - is excellent. This is the story about young magician, who suddenly found himself in center of dramatic events, and story is very well designed. Main character is charismatic and i feel sympathy for him. When the chaos is right there and even the wisest can not find anything better than escape, even then someone just need to stand and fight while he can.

I really liked the fact that in Loom player do not need to collect a bunch of strange stuff and use it in weird illogical combinations, as we usually do in hundreds of another generic quests". In Loom we play as a magician who interacts with surrounding world by using his magic. To cast a spell

reviewText:
LOOM is the work of art from Lucasarts, who back in the past were a dominant game developer. Released back in 1990, this point and click adventure game became one of the best known of Lucasarts enormous library.

You play the role of Bobbin, a wizard who is ready to see the council to become a full pledged wizard. As he gets to the council the higher elders are cast into swans so they can escape 'Chaos'.
It is up to the player to help the higher wizards return to the world and close the gates of chaos's world forever, where you must solve the hardest of puzzles, and of course master the grand instrument 'LOOM'.

This game is amazing. The music is absolutely stunning, soothing, and really captures the mood of the game. Sure, It's a hard game, and without writing down each spell you are stuck, but with that all checked, this game is definately worth It's weight in gold.

LOOM is a must buy for anyone who loves the point and click genre. It's a game which cannot be missed on Steam.

A welcome blast from my childhood. I have played ths many times over the years and am very plesaed that it has made it's way on to Steam.

You play as Bobbin Threadbare, son of Lady Cigna and memeber of the mysterious guild of Weavers. Left alone and the Weavers shadowy Island of Loom you must travel the world in search of your guild learning through experence the the Power of the Distaff and 4 musical notes. A very simple and charming interferace this game is the perfect place to let your younf child entre the world of adventre games.

Unfortauntly this is the 1992 abridged talkie" version of the game but it can be modified to restore it to it's original glory."
Confusingly charming and charmingly confused, this adventuring classic is only spoiled by the bittersweet cliffhanger ending.
This game is completely underrated. Despite the unfortunate downside of having no way to save, the gameplay is unique and the voice work is excellent. I would recommend this game.
Loom is awesome, unique and poetic. It features two of my favorite lines of dialogue ever:\nMy destiny is in your hands

One of the best quest adventures with high replayability.

Unlike other LucasArts adventure games, the story of Loom is more of an elaborate fairytale rather than a classical adventure. It centers on two tropes well known from fantasy stories: the creation of worlds and objects through weaving, and magical music spells. In the course of the game, the player has to play the notes of the spells (called drafts") in order to manipulate the environment. As a newly learned draft is often not immediately used
date: it's advisable to jot down the music sequences in order to have the right spell ready at the right time. I can recommend the game to anyone with a penchant for good storytelling."

Awesome game i played this as a kid and it brought back fun memories replaying this game. Its a traditional point and click adventure game with a little twist on how to progress, make sure you bring pen and paper...erm... well have your notepad ready to right down the drafts and gets readying for LOOM!\n\nIts a little on the short side but if you remember the fun times with Lucas Games and Point and Click games you should try LOOM!

This is a great game from my childhood, but as the others have mentioned, it is missing a few key elements. Most of the changes I can live with (colours, headshots), but I find I do miss the sound effects and the voiceovers are... just ok. I find talking in the game weird, to be honest. Don't get me wrong, though. This is definitely one I'm going to finish.

So, in summary:
If you're a fan of LucasArts, snap it up and play it through, and you'll be glad you did.
If you're looking for high graphics and tremendous action, move along... move along.
GO OUT AND BUY LOOM TODAY!

reviewText:
LOOM is somewhat of an oddity or one might call it an experiment. It doesn't look like other LucasArts adventure games and it doesn't play like them.

You learn short melodies that become your powers and you use them at your own choosing at appropriate points and on appropriate objects during the adventure to make some progress, all while listening to classical music.

It isn't very long or complicated and its more something you have to experience, though it's definitely a more traditional game (i.e. it doesn't play like Dear Esther or Journey or any of those games where you typically make progress without much gameplay mechanics required on your part).

LOOM is a very old game now. I enjoyed it and I think it should be tried at only $4.99 on Steam at the time of writing.

reviewText:
Ultimately, it was difficult for me to choose whether to choose yes or no for this game - I enjoyed myself (although I tend to be notoriously easy to please), but I don't think I would recommend this one to most of my friends.

Loom is a point and click adventure game which focuses on the use of a music to invoke magic to solve problems. The story feels a little disconnected, although it does make sense within the world, but in an odd change from the usual inventory management of these sorts of games, I didn't find the music methodology to be exceedingly engaging. I did not play the original (which apparently had a more involved story) so that might have helped to grab my attention a little bit more.

The game's alright. Not great, but not bad. There's just better examples of the point and click adventure game genre on Steam, so unless you're REALLY into this genre, it's probably not your thing.

reviewText:
I'll divide this review into two sections. One for the point and click veterans and one for those who haven't played it before.

For the new players first:

Loom is closer to being a point and click than anything else adventure but it is unique. There are no inventory based puzzles, and only a few conversation based puzzles. Instead your character makes progress by casting 4 note long musical spells. Figuring out which spell you need can be as challenging as many traditional point and click puzzles.

The game is short but it has a properly charming storyline set in a completely weird fairytale-like universe. I think that alone is enough to make it worth its price. It also has 3 difficulty settings since a lot of the game is based on music. So it doesn't matter if you're tone deaf, pick the easiest setting and you'll not lose any of the game.

Reasons to play it... In spite of its age, Loom has a truly arresting atmosphere, an intriguing and mysterious plot and great atmosphere. The difficulty settings allow anyone to play and enjoy it.

Reasons to not play it.... very few... if you can't handle outdated graphics, if you only like object based puzzles... and you really need the sound on so don't buy it if you hate Tchaikovksy. The background music is mostly Tchaikovsky.

For veterans such as myself:
This is a very faithful update that has caused me no trouble working on modern windows machines.
There has been some very decent voice acting attached to the game. The only negative is that the inclusion of voice acting meant that the producers had to cut down the dialogue so what was already a short game is even shorter.

reviewText: This is the first point & click adventure I played, many moons ago when it first released on Mac.  I still love it to this day, and replay it every so often.  The voice work is great, the puzzles are a little difficult at times, but that was the style back then.  I'd love to see this game get the Monkey Island treatment, but I doubt that will ever happen.  If you're a fan of adventure games, definitely check this one out.

reviewText: When this came out, I remember that I had to get a New Sound Blaster Audio Card to hear the notes because the sound card that came with my computer would not work.  It was this game that made me notice the audio card made the difference in the quality of a game.  I really enjoyed this game, but I really wish that the graphics was better.  I place the graphics in this game on the same level as Space Quest i.  Items are hard to find and gets a little frustrating, but the overall theme of the game is very good.  The story is what made me buy this game again

reviewText: I had a good time playing Loom. It's an adventure game that does away with a lot of the previous staples of adventure games, and tells an interesting story in a creative world. It's been a while since I played it last, but there were two negatives I can remember: it takes a bit too long to explore the world, and some of the songs required to finish the game weren't properly explained, and I had to look them up. Despite that, I enjoyed it, but it's not for everyone.\n\nIf this sounds like your style of game, $5 will be worth it. If not, there are better adventure games to look in to (like most of the Telltale Games).

reviewText: Play this version rather than the EGA or FM-Towns version (ScummVM still hasn't made a useable version with inputs for pixel-perfect aspect ratio adjustment). The voice acting is worth hearing. The edits made removing the character close-up portraits are for the best (they're poorly drawn and don't have formative lip-sync anyway, and the animation is minor. Any scene deletions aren't important to the plot. The game can be beaten on Expert in about three or four hours tops if a walkthrough is used. Play it for the story and the acting--adventure games seem to run along very similar lines and there's nothing that makes it do what others do any differently--your inventory is just moved into memorized sequences, so it's not like the game has no inventory. The writing is kind of confusing, with techno-magic babble confounding things. The audio drama is available online and worth listening to, since it's pretty much bare soundstage play acting (and since the acting is the best part of the game). The music is the most public domain-y generic stuff you can hope for, but it least it's not fully orchestrated and is MIDI (if you're going to listen to an orchestral version, don't go to a game to get the best arrangement of this particular song that repeats almost the entire stinking game with no contextual changes like in later LucasArts games). The story doesn't wrap itself up well, instead of ending on an ending, it ends on a beginning. If you're going to end on a beginning, tell the rest of the story, otherwise you've released a one-thirds finished story. Nice art design and acceptable animation, but nothing that will make someone's top roundup of vintage game art. Play it as a slightly interactive cutscene, not as a game. 30%.

Game is about a kid who always wears hood up because he has bad skin.  The kid is ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ child who not wanted.  When everyone turn to swan for no reason he gets blame so steals magic staff to turn white into green.

After turning everything white to green he breaks into glass shop, then scares campers, burn a dragon before getting blacksmith killed.  He then use Pele power to make sword not straight.  The kid is bad news who does nothing good but only make mess for others.

Finally kid turn into swan and leaves world in a mess.  No follow up game made so story just end with everything in bad way.  Maybe game is a prequel to Scotland.

The game is pretty short and not very hard.  Like a semi.
Classic  adventure game, you learn spells as short mellodies, if you have an ear for music, best played on the hardest level (no visual clues, mellody heard only).

This game is a classic for a reason.  Even though it is short for an old-time adventure game, it possesses a number of fantastic qualities.  The world of Loom, being revealed only in very broad strokes by what we would now consider very primitive graphics, is evocative in a way that many other games fail to achieve.  The gameplay, in which one uses notes played on a magic staff to produce various 'drafts', sort of like magic spells, to solve problems is a fascinating mechanic.  The ending hints at a continious that never was, which is a tad bitter-sweet, but I'd still highly recommend the game.

Loom is a short point and click game about a mage bobbin who sets off on a journey. Point and click story 101.
Loom's story is pretty decent though the ending kinda leaves ya wanting a lot more.
Gamplay is easy as pie you just have to remember the letters that match the staff sounds (on expert no letters which is more difficult)
Ive been told this port of the game is missing cut scenes, dialoge and has been censored i.e. blood.
There are parts of the game that just make ya smile XD but other parts that leave ya kinda questioning WTF.
it is not the best point and click game but it is far from the worst.
I kinda feel the game is mediocre and if you gave it a miss you would not be missing out on much but if your into point and click games in a big way i guess a play through will not harm ya.
Audio and Body laungage is not synced too great either but kinda expected for the time this game came out.

5/10 Id recomend on looking to see if you can the complete version of this game from GoG they tend to have full versions of old games without no content being removed.

There also is a fan made sequel to the game going around on the internet known as FORGE""

Loom is a click to move or identify things type game and came out when DOS and Windows3.1 was around. (This version has been remastered so it runs on your current operating system and they've added sounds which weren't previously in the old version).

To play Loom your likely to want to get a piece of paper as in the game you learn spells from word combinations.  For example. G G G H = twist, but H G G G = untwist.
When you learn a combination you simply do it backwards to get the opposite effect.  Its just trial and error mainly but you learn each spell by looking around and its handy to have paper to write down the combinations as it can be quite easy to forget which combination is which.

Loom is another one of Lucasart's classic games, but rather then have an inventory and objects, you use music to solve your puzzles. Set in a possible distant future or in another world, you play Bobbin Threadbare, a weaver who is forced watch his people disappear and must go on a search for their location. Armed with a piece of wood called a distaff, you have to travel to different locations and solve puzzles by the way of music, 4 note combinations that can do anything from turn things green to fill goblets with wine. The Steam version is the up-dated version Lucasarts released some years ago and features re-mastered music and full speech.
One of the best pieces of my childhood. I love it
Stunningly awesome, even though its old. Completed it twice. :)
You Need Thiz Game!!

Though not entirely forgotten, LOOM is rarely the first game mentioned on a list of SCUMM engine masterworks. Make no mistake, however, because it is brilliant and immersive.

Unlike most SCUMM games, LOOM is rarely funny, and tries its very best to build a universe taht you can believe in. Also, its soundtrack (and various story elements) originate from the Tchaikovsky masterwork Swan Lake, serving to bolster the games lofty high brow tones and sense of believability.

Given its dirt cheap cheapness, its hard to think of a reason not to play through this once, simply to say you've experienced it.
It's a point and click game that is good.

Loom is a fantasic example of how to shake up the adventure game formula.  There are no tedious fetch quests, no massive inventory management and a good story to boot.  It's not perfect.  It is quite short by adventure game terms and very linear, but as a nice concept it's good to see that LucasArts tried to diversify a bit.

Be aware that the steam version is the inferior CD Talkie with some missing content.  However, if you go to http://steamreview.org/external/loom/ you can download the original version and see the whole story.

All in all, good fun.   Give it a go.
A real classic. I used to play this on my old IBM Aptiva with a Pentium 2 mmx. Ah those were the days. Great to relive old times. Don't have it? Get it.

Great adventure. I remember watching my mother playing it back when it came out like two decades ago, but never had the occasion to play it myself. I really enjoyed the puzzles and even had a laugh or two. That said, it's quite short and easy compared to other LucasArts titles (or so it seemed to me), even playing it on expert mode. Also, I ran the FM-TOWNS non-voiced version that can be downloaded here: http://steamreview.org/external/loom/ (after purchasing it on steam), which seems to have some dialogs and scenes lacking on the voiced version here available.
Fun, good story, unique spin on point and click adventure games, not too difficult once you understand what each draft does.  It's a shame the sequals were never made.\n\nAbout 4-5 hours of gameplay

Provides a good and rare feeling of well developed story. Point-and-click quest stands a bit out of the row due to an original spell cast system. A bit melancholic, but impressively grasping story development. By the way, one of the three cases in my whole gaming experience when a game played through in the distant 1990s deserved another completion in 2014.

reviewText: The latest bomb from master storyteller Morrie Brianmarty, BOOM is a post-holocaust adventure set in the post-holocaust America after the holocaust. Neutron bombs have eradicated all life, leaving only YOU to wander through the wreckage. No other characters, no conflict, no puzzles, no chance of dying and no interface make this the easiest-to-finish game yet! Just boot it up and watch it explode!\n\nWait, wrong game. It's actually a fun little game filled with drama and colourful characters in an epic setting set to the music of Tchaikovsky.

This is a beautiful game and a masterpiece in my opinion. It is like playing in a lucid dream; the game is old, but the art is still gorgeous. The story is very original. The music is enigmatic, tranquil and blissful.

I enjoyed every moment of Loom, but I really wish the sequel was made; the ending is good, but some loose ends were not tied up. The game is an ethereal beauty and a special memory.

An old game from the 1990;s however this was one of the games along side the legendary The Secret of Monkey Island" series that made adveture games what they are now. You need to re-visit these games to see the true form of adventure games. With LOOM you need to have a pencil ready to write down musical notes. If you have a ear for musical notes then this should not be a problem. LOOM has a great story line (which I won't spoil here)
date: but you need to see it to experience it. The ending was not what I thought...\n\nCheers to the Monkey Island Series however. .... Damn great adventure game franchise...."
